subject: open_power: Inventory: Added the "Chiplet" item
commitMessage:
open_power: Inventory: Added the "Chiplet" item

In an OpenPOWER based system, the application can isolate
chiplet hardware in the error path if the hardware is fault,
and the respective isolated hardware part will be ignored to
init during the next boot of the host.

This chiplet inventory item interface will be used to add
the different types of chiplets into bmc inventory and the same
can be used by the application to get/set additional attributes
to those chiplet types, for example,
xyz::openbmc_project::Inventory::Item.PrettyName etc...

Signed-off-by: Ramesh Iyyar <rameshi1@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Ibd286cbd7d4e0379685cace4d1955ce47f903837

OpenPOWER

Sorry, I am not sure whether you are looking latest patch. 
I have fixed this based on other commit's comments.
looks like i missed to publish my earlier comments :) and it published with latest reveiw comments
boot
same as above
Guardable units? No chiplet items in the the processor subunits also guardble . Update commit message accordingly.

I have discussed with the hostboot team on this patch.

The discussion point is, all the chiplet items (which are present as chiplet type in this patch) are not subunits of chiplet, and it is all about how we packaged processor subunits for a machine.

Looks, we need to model a separate inventory item for all the isolatable (guardable) FRU/FRU units.

Any different thoughts?

Need to include all the guard able unit info.based on POWER processor spec.
How you are going to handle this list across processor genarations?

> Need to include all the guard able unit info.based on POWER processor spec.

Replied in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/44037/2//COMMIT_MSG#7

> How you are going to handle this list across processor genarations?

I think we need add based on needs if future processor coming with new unit/fru which can be isolated.
I suspect many of these enumeration types are specific to the particular generation of chip you are currently working on.  Should this interface be "P10Chiplet"?

I have discussed with the IBM hostboot team on this patch.

The discussion point is, all the chiplet items (which are present as chiplet type in this patch) are not subunits of chiplet, and it is all about how we packaged processor subunits for a machine.

Looks, we need to model a separate inventory item for all the isolatable (guardable) FRU/FRU units. 

and we (IBM BMC team) discussed this and All are felt like pushing as the separate item will be usable in the future so I am going to push separate inventory item for each type but, I felt like If I have pushed those inventory item into xyz/openbmc_project it may be useful for others because I guess maybe a few are generic and a few are specific to POWER bus - I am in the process of background study to understand each hardware usage (not very familiar with each hardware usage :)) 

Any different thoughts?

> I felt like If I have pushed those inventory item into xyz/openbmc_project it may be useful for others

I'm not sure if any of these on the list here are going to be generally applicable.  Are there any attributes associated with them?  If there aren't any attributes anyhow, I think it is simpler to just keep them in open_power, otherwise we need to discuss with Intel, AMD, Arm and understand if it also matches their hardware design and that will just slow you down.

I've previously worked on P5 thru P9 and none of these chiplets existed for any of those chips except the 'MC' and 'PHB' (and arguably what the 'MC' contained has changed on every processor generation since P5).  I'd still recommend putting these into a subdirectory.  Maybe "Item.Chiplet.Power10.xxx", but ultimately that is up to your team to decide.

> I have discussed with the IBM hostboot team on this patch.
> and we (IBM BMC team) discussed this

It would be good of your team to have discussions in public.  If people on your team have opinions, especially the BMC team itself, they should express those and review your commits.  That way we can know the consensus building around certain directions and you are not having to act as a middle man.

By saying "we discussed this and we decided XXX", the only way I can take that you personally decided.  I don't know who these people are, how large of a group they are, why their opinion should matter, what evidence they brought to the discussion, etc.

> I'm not sure if any of these on the list here are going to be generally applicable. 
Oh ok thanks for your suggestion in the early stage itself - I started this analysis yesterday onwards. You saved my time :). 

> Are there any attributes associated with them? 
I am planning to implement "PrettyName" which is need for hardware isolation to get to know the name of the subunit which is isolated. 

I am not seeing any other attributes now.

> If there aren't any attributes anyhow, I think it is simpler to just keep them in open_power, otherwise we n need to discuss with Intel, AMD, Arm and understand if it also matches their hardware design and that will just slow you down.
Yeah got the pain point. I will try to push into org/openpower then.

> I've previously worked on P5 thru P9 and none of these chiplets existed for any of those chips except the 'MC' and 'PHB' (and arguably what the 'MC' contained has changed on every processor generation since P5).  I'd still recommend putting these into a subdirectory.  Maybe "Item.Chiplet.Power10.xxx", but ultimately that is up to your team to decide.

Ah ok, Thanks for sharing your experience on this, and Yes, "Item.Chiplet.Power10.xxx" makes sense to me but, I will check with the hostboot team who owning those subunits to init.

> It would be good of your team to have discussions in public.  If people on your team have opinions, especially the BMC team itself, they should express those and review your commits.  That way we can know the consensus building around certain directions and you are not having to act as a middle man.

Got it, I just pushed this patch two days back, and Luckily, I got a slot to discuss with the internal team on my patches and got the above feedback from various teams. I got an indication that starts the discussion in discord but, looks you are very fast :)   

> By saying "we discussed this and we decided XXX", the only way I can take that you personally decided.  I don't know who these people are, how large of a group they are, why their opinion should matter, what evidence they brought to the discussion, etc.

Yeah, I can understand, I will make sure that next time onwards I will try to use the community forum.
Is this a mistake?
Looks No. In POWER, they are modelled MCC under MC for example, pervasive bus -> mc -> mi -> mcc
If those are two different things they need two different descriptions.
Yeah got the confusion, I will change it with a more appropriate description.
